#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=2.
#Text=The Development of Some Competitive Cooperatives
#Text=The approach of the theme of the present paper started from “ A Guide to Setting up Cooperatives ” study issued by the International Labor Office in 1984 .
#Text=The fundamental elements of a cooperative are presented in detail within the guide .

#Text=By corroborating the provisions of the guide with the specialty literature in an empirical manner , a series of reciprocal relations , which must exist within any agricultural cooperative , was established (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=) .

#Text=According to Iliopoulos , the traditional agricultural cooperatives must be in a continuous development process in order to be able to resist the market and to cope with the challenges and competition .
#Text=This process is defined by Cook and Burress as a cyclic struggle , with an evolution on five distinct phases .
#Text=The first two phases are represented by the economic justification and the organizational design , which are defining the cooperative setting up stage .
#Text=The following two phases are characteristic of the development stage of the cooperative and its related problems .
#Text=The last phase is represented by the choice of reorganizing or redesigning the activity , of the management , and of the strategies pursued , or by renouncing cooperation .
#Text=In the present study , we aim to analyze the first two phases and the impact of their non-fulfillment on the sustainability and competitiveness of the cooperative .
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=Group — Capital Cohesion
#Text=It represents the stage in which the members have been co-opted within the cooperative , have understood the operating principles , and brought capital to cover the setting up expenses .
#Text=This stage reflects the creation of the core .

#Text=In addition , at this stage , the co-operators must understand that the participation in the cooperative is a medium and long-term investment , and that the initial contribution must be supplemented , together with the maintenance and development of the group cohesion for a harmonious operation of the cooperative .
#Text=The same opinion is also expressed by Bercu , who draws attention on the strengthening of the farmer ’s position in the food chain , in order to combat unfair commercial practices .

#Text=As Cook and Burress state , it is necessary for the members to understand both the benefits of the cooperative ( economic justification ) and its role of common protection of the cooperative members , as compared to the individual risk .
#Text=Problems and difficulties may arise when these elements are not well clarified .
#Text=There is a mutual connection between the trust of the members based on social cohesion and their contribution within the cooperative .

#Text=The involvement of the participants in the cooperative through the capital , in a regulated proportion , represents , in Ostrom ’s opinion , “ a collection of both formal and informal forms and standards ” that determine the members to work together and to cooperate .
#Text=The importance of the share capital within the cooperative is compared by Chloupkova et al. with physical and human capital in trading companies .
#Text=Thus , the size of the member participation in the capital of the cooperative has an important impact on its development and performance .

#Text=The absence of the three elements of the initial stage , which ensures the cohesion of the group , including the trust , capital , and communication between members , discourages their involvement in collective actions .

#Text=Given the complexity of the relationships within a cooperative , represented using each member ’s own production factors and their desire to exercise control and ownership , the cooperatives cannot be viewed in the same way as other enterprises .

#Text=The Copa Cogeca report draws attention to the need for the legislative regulation of cooperative financing in Romania , because they are treated in the same way as commercial companies , without being included in the bank nomenclature .

#Text=Under these conditions , the main financing sources of agricultural cooperatives during the setup phase are represented by the share capital deposited by the members and by accessing non-reimbursable funds/subsidies .
#Text=Based on these aspects , the first proposition of the study was defined .
#Text=Proposition 1.
#Text=Members ’ contribution , which is limited only to covering the minimum capital regulated by law , impacts the competitiveness of the cooperative .
#Text=2.2 .
#Text=Central Collection Space

#Text=In order to comply with the objective of the agricultural cooperative to obtain better prices than by individual trade or by trade immediately after harvest , the existence of at least one collection/storage space of the harvest is important for the sale at advantageous prices .

#Text=The policy of the cooperative in what concerns the sales must be well adapted in order to be able to establish the price , the conditions in which they are prepared to sell , and the collection place .
#Text=According to the type of product/products traded by the cooperative , the collection space must fulfill certain particularities .
#Text=We consider the existence of an adequate space for weighting , selling , and packing products necessary .

#Text=The International Labor Office , through the Guide on the collection of agricultural production , makes a series of determinations regarding the support of transport costs both by the members and the cooperative , diversified according to product categories , perishability , durability , value , and season .
#Text=Proposition 2.
#Text=Without an adequate collection space , the cooperatives cannot develop their activity in optimum conditions .
